This platformer is very difficult. You die if you touch the spikes along the floors and walls, but once you gain a key to exit the level, new hazards -- usually moving -- suddenly appear as well. Marketed as deliberately difficult, it does hide the fact that there is only a thin game here. You can gain coins and purchase hats along the way, but mostly you spend your time dying.

186971.name: Tether 3D
186971.description:
User Summary

The game takes place on an asteroid tethered to Earth by giant lifts.

186972.name: De Bumbatrein
186972.description: Before the game starts you can build up the variable game board that consists of different train pieces. Every piece shows 3 objects in a different color. The players start in the beginning of the train and roll the die. They can move their pawn to the next object on the game board that has the same color as the die. As soon as you roll a color that isn't present between your pawn and the locomotive the player can move his pawn to the locomotive and he or she is the winner of the game.

186974.name: Khe Sanh '68
186974.description:
Khe Sanh ‘68 places you in command of United States and South Vietnamese (ARVN) forces in the campaign to relieve the USMC firebase at Khe Sanh during the Vietnam War. The historical campaign was something of a race against time as the US high command feared that the North Vietnamese were going to attempt to overrun the base. All resources put into the Khe Sanh fight, however, were subtracted from those available to deal with the Tet Offensive elsewhere. Your mission is to extract maximum communist losses while minimizing the allied effort.

The game uses the Cold War Blitz series rules, a solitaire game system. You command the US and ARVN units, and have a deck of cards to enhance your unit capabilities. A second deck of cards, drawn randomly one at a time, controls communist (OPFOR) activities. Combat is resolved with a quasi-tactical system with opposing units firing at one another.

186975.name: Super Dungeon Explore: Jack Scarecrow
186975.description:
Jack Scarecrow is a single miniature expansion for Super Dungeon Explore. The box contains the Jack Scarecrow model, cards to use the miniature as a hero or mini-boss, and one unique treasure card.

Given life by cackling hedge wizards and village crones, Scarecrows are charged with protecting both village and farm from the predation of the Dark Consul's monsters. Old Jack was the first Scarecrow given life by over-eager farmers a century ago. Unfortunately, the farmers' crude hedge magic was easily corrupted by the Dark Consul. Now Jack is a scourge upon the very villages and farms he was created to protect.

186976.name: Phantasmal Lights
186976.description:
User summary:

The peculiar core rule book includes interleaved chapters of game rules and fiction in about equal proportions. Early game chapters deal with role-playing from an introductory perspective. The game uses fairly unique terminology to refer to fairly standard role-playing aspects (for example, the Game Master is referred to as the Director). Character creation is inordinately complex and heavily numeric; task resolution is fairly simple. Generally, tasks are resolved by rolling 1d10 and adding a modifier, then comparing the result to a target difficulty. Determining which modifier to use may be problematic.

Character creation begins with Personality Factors which are intended to guide the character's action during the game. There are ten Personality Factors and each one has a pair of sub-factors. Personality Factors always have a Rating of 10, but those points are distributed among the two sub-factors in any combination from 1:9 through 5:5 to 9:1, indicating how extreme the behavior of that Personality Factor should be. The Personality Factors are Brave/Cowardly; Caution/Impulsive; Energetic/Indolent; Extrovert/Introvert; Forgiving/Vengeful; Gentle/Cruel; Honest/Deceitful; Modest/Proud; Optimist/Pessimist; and Trusting/Suspicious.

Characters next have ten Primary Characteristics divided into Mental and Physical Sets. The Mental Set includes Determination, Education, Intelligence, Intuition, and Presence. The Physical Set includes Dexterity, Essence, Physique, Stamina, and Strength. All Primary Characteristics start at 1 and the player then distributes 20 additional points among the Mental Set and 20 additional points among the Physical Set. If any Primary Characteristic is ever reduced to zero the character dies. Characters next have several Secondary Characteristics which are either randomly generated, derived from Primary Characteristics, or purchased from a points pool. Secondary Characteristics include Age, Height, Initiative, Kick, Life, Load, Mass, Punch, Speed, and Throw.

Characters next have Abilities (normally called Skills in typical RPGs). All characters have at least on Ability and most characters will have more. Abilities are divided into Career Abilities and Life Abilities. Abilities have a Rating ranging from 1 to 5 and are purchased from a point pool. Abilities also have Concentrations (specific areas of expertise within the Ability), Designates (a particular area the Concentration covers), and Specializations (specific areas of expertise within the Concentration). A few pages of sample Ability/Concentration examples are provided.

Magic is handled as an Ability (Skill) with additional axes. The Magic Ability is divided into Principals (normally called Schools in typical RPGs) and Disciplines (normally called spell type in typical RPGs). For example, the Magic Ability might have the Principal of "Death/Life" and the Discipline "Destruction". Likewise, combat is handled as a series of Abilities.

Characters also may have Attributes (normally called Advantages/Disadvantages in typical RPGs). Several pages of sample Attributes, with associated Levels, are provided. Characters receive an Allowance (a monthly income) and a narrative background. Characters gain Development Points through game participation; these may be spent to improve numeric Ratings.

As expected, the included character sheet is two pages long and resembles a spreadsheet.

186977.name: Precipitate
186977.description:
The Fascinating Game of Chemical Formulas.

The idea of the game is to arrange cards as to form compounds letting each card represent an atom. Each player must have the correct number and kinds of cards for the compound being made, i.e. H2O - must have one oxygen card and two hydrogen cards.

Game is similar to rummy. Players dealt 9 cards. One draw pile and one discard pile (starting with one card up.) Players draw one card (from either pile) and discard one card on turn. Play continues until one player has all cards in had made into compounds. Player lays all cards down and calls out "Precipitate."

Every player gets score for cards made into compounds, points increasing for number of cards per compound. Player who called "Precipitate" gets 10 points. Game played until one player has 100 points.

Game can be played with any number of players (solitaire directions included) but best with 2-6.

186978.description:
An expansion to 18Ruhr, allowing players to cut the playable map in half. It also adds the following things:


two new private companies;
mixed Montan companies, allowing both coal and steel mines simultaneously;
new tiles;
the Dortmunder Hafenbahn, an additional (industrial) railway.
186978.name: 18Ruhr: Extension 01

boardgameintegration: Ghost Hunter
Ghost Hunter: Monsters
Ghost Hunter: Vampires
Ghost Hunter
Ghost Hunter: Monsters
Ghost Hunter: Vampires
186979.description:
This Halloween the land has been blighted by an unnatural curse. Crops have rotted in the fields, feral beasts stalk the villages and children wake with night terrors.The ever vigilant members of the Infernal Club have discovered the source of the corruption. Witches!!!As one of the club’s supernatural enforcers it is the players' duty to conduct a witch hunt and capture as many of the coven as they dare.

Ghost Hunter: Witches is a card game for 2 or more players (up to 6 with one deck or 12 with two decks). Players must lay down higher and higher Witch cards until one can lay a set of three capturing all the cards on the table at that time. A player who cannot keep up with the witches being laid will be forced to pick up the stack and add it to their hand. Every captured card is worth points at the end of the game. Many cards have special rules that effect the order of play, who may capture or other game dynamics. Some cards are marked as 'innocent' meaning that if they are captured, which is often unavoidable, they are worth minus points at the end of the game. When the first player has gotten rid of all of their cards the game ends, then the player who has the most positive points wins overall with the others being ranked behind them based on their scores.

The deck can be integrated with all the other Ghost Hunter decks like the blues Spirits deck or the red Vampires deck.

So assemble your trusted associates, light your torches and prepare for the wickedness of Ghost Hunter: Witches.
186979.name: Ghost Hunter: Witches

186980.description: Holdfast North Africa 1941-1942 is the follow up to the highly popular Holdfast Russia 1940-1941 and Holdfast Korea 1950-51. The game uses simple mechanics with a highly interactive turn sequence that keeps gamers engaged for a fast, fun, and furious 2 to 2.5 hours of play. The game units are blocks with labels and a low unit density on board means the game does not bog down. The core rules are 4 pages expanded to 8 with detailed graphics and explanations meaning you can be up and playing with 15 minutes of rules reading and a short set up.
186980.name: HoldFast: North Africa 1941-1942

186981.name: Fossil Hunters
186981.description:
Fossil Hunters is a game of area encirclement for 2-5 players. All players have access to the same slab of rock. The goal is to split it apart, divide the spoils, and form complete dinosaur skeletons. Large dinosaurs are much more lucrative, but incomplete skeletons do not score!

Using wooden sticks to divide the board, players collectively determine which tiles will be claimed and by whom. As the board splits and shrinks, players are pressured to finish what they've started before every fossil is claimed. Timing is everything, so sometimes it is best to take a partial turn and conserve resources for later. Each player also holds a unique single-use tool. This should be employed at the best moment for the greatest reward.

Fossil Hunters is a short small-box game, taking only 20 minutes to play.

186982.name: Superstatic
186982.description:
User Summary

After a prison break, you eliminate enemies and take their weapons. You connect with a former prisoner and learn about secret powers that you now have. The action is top-down, the graphics simplistic, but there is one innovation in that you can create 'copies' to allow you take possession of enemies and explode in crowded enemy areas.

186983.name: Presto
186983.description:
From the designer:

"Many musicians, even those of considerable experience, frequently have difficulty in sight reading music and it is often necessary for them to play a selection a number of times before they can be assured of rendering it with accuracy. This is due largely to the fact that many musicians are not sufficiently familiar with the positions of the notes of the musical scale to be able to recognize instantly a given note from its position, which is essential in sight reading. This is especially true of beginners or persons inexperienced in reading music." This game aims to teach the notes of the scale through game play. Includes board, 48 cards and 16 playing pieces, four of each color.

The board has the treble staff and the bass staff running continuously around the board with the musical notes of the scale on them, with the name of the note in small letters. Players have four game pieces each. The object is to move through the notes of the scales to get all four game pieces to the W-I-N-S zone. The players turn cards to determine what letter of the scale to move to. At first they may need to refer to the names of the notes, but as the game is played, they will begin to recognize the position of the notes, aiding in their sight reading ability. Players may move any of their pieces, and may have to move backward in order to get to the note indicated. The first player to get all his pieces in the W-I-N-S zone is the winner.

186984.name: Life Is Strange: Episode 5 – Polarized
186984.description:
User summaery

The final installment of the series, where the super storm edges ever closer towards Arcadia Bay.

186985.name: Hipster: The Card Game
boardgameintegration: Hipster: Teenage Wasteland
Hipster: Teenage Wasteland
186985.description:
The Hippest of the Hip

Strategy is the name of the game as you compete to be the coolest in town in the game of Hipster. Collect your gear and play against others in your quest to be hipper than everyone else. But watch out, because once things become too cool they’re no longer cool.

In Hipster you want to be cooler than everyone else, and you want to do it first. Each player gets five cards at the start of the game, and they're each trying to match up three cards in front of them with the three cards in the center. Those center cards are "What's Cool Right Now" and the only way to win is to be cool like those cards.

But watch out: if too many people get into those center cards, those "Cool" cards are no longer cool, and the central cards go away, replaced by the latest, hippest thing in town. What's cool is always changing, ever shifting, so if you want to be hip you gotta live on the edge, adapting quickly to win the game.

Hipster features are selection of cards, with three different "Cool" card suits -- Culture, Fashion, and Trinkets -- along with instant cards you can play on others, Play When You Want cards, and new rules you can introduce to change the rules of the gam, Damn the Man cards. To win the game, you have to be fast, you have to be quick, and above all, you have to be the coolest, hippest hipster around.

186986.name: Kung Fu Panda: The Board Game
186986.description:
In Kung Fu Panda: The Board Game, you play as either Po or one of the Furious Five (Tigress, Monkey, Mantis, Crane and Viper), with everyone working together to defeat Tai Lung and other villains from the Kung Fu Panda films and animated series through intense dice-rolling action. By defeating villains, completing quests and helping others, players will gain karma to upgrade their character's abilities and secure the use of legendary artifacts from Master Shifu with which to face even deadlier perils.

Each of the heroes in Kung Fu Panda: The Board Game will be represented by a custom miniature.

186987.description:
Snowstorms, tornadoes, scorching heat.
Face the elements and hope they are on your side!

5 cardboard figures + 5 plastic stands + 40 cards
186987.name: The 7th Continent: Facing the Elements

186989.name: Phoenix Command High Speed Pursuit System
186989.description:
From the introduction:

The Phoenix Command High Speed Pursuit System (PCHSPS) is designed to let you simulate the use and abuse of common civilian wheeled motor vehicles, especially those involved in high-speed pursuits, while providing a realistic sense of the dangers and decisions involved. It is compatible with other Phoenix Command products, but the game stands alone and requires little or no familiarity with them. Players should find the rules satisfy both role-play and miniatures purposes, and can be modulated to taste.

186990.name: Suez '56: Anglo French Intervention in Egypt
186990.description:
Suez ‘56 places you in command of British, French, and Israeli forces in Operation Musketeer, the invasion of Egypt. The historical objective was to regain control of the Suez Canal and potentially remove Egypt’s President Nasser. Your mission is to achieve those objectives while avoiding the political debacle that marred the actual event.

The game uses the Cold War Blitz series rules, a solitaire game system. You command the allied units, and have a deck of cards to enhance your unit capabilities. A second deck of cards, drawn randomly one at a time, controls Egyptian (OPFOR) activities. Combat is resolved with a quasi-tactical system with opposing units firing at one another. The game ends after the last turn, but you control when that is through the judicious play of your cards (the OPFOR cards can affect it too).

Skills:
• Level: Brigade
• Hex: 14.5 miles per inch

186991.description:
Apicultura is a card drafting, resource conversion game about breeding bees, harvesting honey and selling it to maximize your profit.

The player at the end of the game who has collected the most income is the winner.

In Apicultura, each player has a player board representing their own individual honey farm and a hand of identical action cards.

At the start of the game the players begin with 2 lowly Level A hives (these can be upgraded later).

Every turn the Action Cards are drafted which allow players to Breed Bees (add a new hive in a space where there are already 2 hives), Plant Fields (increasing the maximum number of hives permitted), Produce Honey ("spending" hives for the round to generate honey), Upgrade Hives which increases the quality (and value) of the honey produced and as well as Sell Honey (either to exclusive honey boutiques or direct to the public at a reduced rate) depending on the demand for their particular product. The honey can also be marketed or refined which can increases its value, or simply opt to generate a small amount of income.
186991.name: Apicultura

186992.name: Picking Sides
186992.description:
User summary:

The game is based upon a novel (by the same author) and attempts to re-create the tone and setting of the novel, though the rules could easily be adapted to any setting. Magic in the system is elemental and all effects are tied to one of seven types of element: fire, water, earth, air, wood, metal, and spirit. Each element has a specific area in which it works best.

Characters have typical demographic data determined with narrative tags. Characters also have a flaw--either wrath, envy, gluttony, sloth, lust, greed, or pride. Characters select an element. Characters have seven Attributes (Agility, Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Belief, Manipulation, and Technology) among which the player distributes a total of 280 points from a pool. Characters may also have Skills which have another pool of 280 points distributed among them. Skills may improve with use. The game lists several sample Skills but it is up to the player to select whatever Skills their character should have.

Action resolution involves a d100 roll; "rolling under" a Skill or Attribute indicates success. The Game Master may modify the role (generally up to +/- 30) based on difficulty. Magic is handled under a separate system and depends upon the character's Level with the Element upon which the magic is based. Levels run 1-6 for characters, with 3 being typical. Under normal circumstances, a Level 1 magic use has a 50% chance to succeed, with each subsequent level boosting the chance by 10%.

186993.name: Vortex: The Gateway
186993.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – AVAILABLE




This game is still either in Early-Alpha or Beta (or any status in between) but IS already available for sale / early access, so CAN BE PLAYED.




Due to a mysterious dimension vortex you will find yourself on an alien planet. Explore, adapt, build and fight to survive. You will have to face the dangers of the planet at different times of day, at changing temperature, hungry or thirsty. You can explore spectacular and dangerous places where you always remain a prey for the local species.

If you want to survive then be alert, sneak, build and fight. Meanwhile life back on Earth changes dramatically. What changes? You will get bits of information through your adventure. Prepare for the worst!

Source: The Game Website.

186994.name: Pinion
186994.description:
User summary:

Pinion resolution uses 2d10 but a 1d20 variant is provided.

Characters have Primary Stats (Attributes) divided into Body (Strength, Prowess, Physique), Mind (Reason, Perception, Knowledge), and Spirit (Will, Sentience, Potency). Characters also have Derived Stats including Movement, Toughness, and Vitality. Primary Stats can be randomly determined or purchased form a point pool; humans have Primary Stats in the 1-20 range with a typical value being 6-7. Characters have Advantages and Disadvantages which can be purchased from the same point pool used for Primary Stats. Characters also have Skills with numeric ratings similar to Primary Stats. However, the Skill lists provided are examples only and the game Skill list will depend upon the "Interlock" (genre expansion module) being used.

Non-trivial tasks are resolved by rolling 2d10 and "rolling under" the appropriate Skill or Primary Stat. In opposed actions both opponents roll and the one with the greatest difference between their roll and Skill wins. In unopposed actions the roll must be lower than the Skill by some Task Difficulty established by the Lawgiver (Game Master). Combat is handled with an appropriate Skill (Shoot, Throw, Strike, Claw, Punch, Kick, Bite, or Fight) as an opposed action (usually by Dodge, Parry, or Block). Extended rules apply to rapid-fire firearms, multiple attacks, hand-to-hand attacks, and other special maneuvers.

186995.description:
Description from the publisher:

"Exterminate!" They muttered about their sacred hatred, the Oncoming Storm. Their creator had a plan, a plan to make the Daleks great again. A plan to turn all their defeats into victories. A plan to remove the one variable that has always interfered with the master plan. The Doctor must be erased from time itself!

Ever wanted to be the Doctor? Travel in time and space, meet companions and have adventures? In Doctor Who: Time of the Daleks you do just that, with every player picking a Doctor and trying to thwart the Daleks' master plan of erasing the Doctor from history. Do you have what it takes to fill a Time Lord's Shoes? Join us on an adventure in space and time with a game that is bigger on the inside...
186995.name: Doctor Who: Time of the Daleks
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 18 - The 2016 Blitzies
Episode 193

186996.name: Pub Battles: Brandywine
186996.description:
Pub Battles: Brandywine is meant to be played out. It is rugged enough to withstand spilled drinks at your favorite café or restaurant. It is fast and simple: 1 hour play time and 1 page rules. The stunning Kriegspiel style hardwood blocks on a real commander’s style canvas map looks like the real thing.


Mini style movement.
Bucket of Dice style combat.
Formations move by random chit pull.
Leaders can alter the move sequence and rally pieces before combat.


Washington sets up first. The British can attack from either flank or the center, recreating the historical sense of surprise for the battle and providing great re-playability.

186997.name: High Octane
186997.description:
From the introduction:

High Octane is a slightly more serious, possibly more complicated, and hopefully still fun expansion for Risus.

User summary:

The expansion lists numerous Clichés to use during character generation. In this expansion, Clichés have three components--a name, a number of dice, and a scope. For example: Psycho Killer, 4, Butchering people with household objects.

The document includes Swords & Sorcery genre notes as well as "bonus rules" for traps and spells. Also included are Science Fiction notes. Also included are a weapons list and optional rules for modern genre gaming. For the Game Master, some notes on NPCs and locations also are included.

186998.name: The Reverse RPG
186998.description:
User summary:

The Revers RPG is a rules-light and lighthearted role-playing game where players don't get to decide what their characters do--but they do get to decide whether they succeed at doing it. Players grab a handful of mixed marbles (black, white, and a few red) and then as the Game Master outlines the narrative, characters determine success or failure by playing (discarding) either a white or black marble, respectively. Another player may then play a red marble to reverse the decision. Players don't get to grab another handful of marbles until they've played out the first handful--including red ones.

Character creation is exceptionally simple and involves defining Attributes and then arranging them across a dice number spread. When an action is taken, the player rolls a dice, finds the Attribute, and must proceed to resolve the situation in that manner (e.g., using that Attribute). The GM narrates the campaign; the players narrate the action scenes.

186999.name: Epitaph
186999.description:
User summary:

Epitaph is a campaign setting for the Fudge system. The setting does implement some variant rules and specific rules but they are fairly minor variations on the basic system.

The setting is heavily engaged with the history of the world and the cosmology. There are various geographical realms detailed as well, and power factions that span the globe. Generally speaking, the scope of the campaign is epic and the assumption is that characters will be fully developed and quite powerful during standard play.

187000.name: Block Out!
187000.description:
Stack blocks and be the first player to get rid of all your cards, or win the game anytime by succesfully playing the 9th block on the stack.

Each player gets 7 cards. Each turn a player has to play a card. If the player cannot play a card, the he/she draws cards until a card comes up that can be played.
Playing a block card: Choose a block that isn't on the stack already and which matches the card. Attempt to place it on the stack. You can only use one hand, and the stack had to stay in place for at least 3 seconds.
Playing an action card: There are two kinds of action cards. Pass your turn and reverse play order.
